<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
static int irq_notify_fd
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C Rule 17.8 concerns modifying function parameters (the pointer value itself shall not be modified; the object pointed-to may be). The function metal_linux_irq_notify has no parameters, so there are no local function parameters inside this function that could be modified. Local variables (val, ret) and the global irq_notify_fd are not function parameters and do not violate Rule 17.8 by being assigned to or used. The only places to inspect for potential Rule 17.8 issues are calls where pointers/parameters are passed to other functions: the write(...) call (passes a pointer &val) and the metal_log(...) invocation (expands to a call to _metal.common.log_handler). Also inspect the metal_log macro expansion to ensure the log handler implementation does not modify pointer parameters in violation of the rule. No other fragments in the provided code contain function parameters being modified, so they do not need investigation for Rule 17.8.
